posts._title: Shôhei Imamura – Karayuki-san AKA The Making of a Prostitute (1975)
posts.title: Karayuki-san
posts.excerpt: Quote: A film about another kind of “unreturned soldier” than Shohei Imamura has profiled elsewhere, KARAYUKI-SAN finds the filmmaker traveling to Malaysia to interview Kikuyo Zendo, one of the countless Japanese women who were kidnapped or otherwise sold into sexual slavery in order to service the Japanese military in Southeast Asia. 74 years old at …

posts.title: Évolution
posts.excerpt: The only residents of young Nicholas’s seaside town are women and boys. When he sees a dead body in the ocean one day, he begins to question his existence and surroundings. Why must he, and all the other boys, be hospitalised? Nicolas is a boy living on a remote island set in the future, or …

posts._title: Vitali Kanevsky – Samostoyatelnaya zhizn aka An Independent Life (1992)
posts.title: Samostoyatelnaya zhizn
posts.excerpt: on the road again… This is the second instalment of a three-part series of autobiographical films about the director’s life. The first, which won various awards for its maker, was entitled Zamri Oumi Voskresni and was later retitled Zari, Umri, Vokresni (“Freeze-Die-Come to Life). At the end of that film, set at the conclusion of …

posts.title: Abluka
posts.excerpt: SYNOPSIS/PLOT: Amid the intense political violence of Istanbul, Kadir is released on parole two years early on the condition that he become an informant for the police gathering terrorist informations, activities, and searching for bombs on trash cans.

posts._title: Ciro Guerra – El abrazo de la serpiente AKA Embrace of the Serpent (2015)
posts.title: El abrazo de la serpiente
posts.excerpt: Quote: “You are nothing but a white!” So shouts indigenous Amazonian shaman Karamakate (Nilbio Torres) to the seemingly on-the-level but still suspicious German scientist/explorer Theodor (Jan Bijvoet) in Ciro Guerra’s enthralling, politically tinged, psychedelic, historical adventure film Embrace of the Serpent. Reversing the perspective of more familiar movies such as Werner Herzog’s Fitzcarraldo or Roland …

posts.title: Työmiehen päiväkirja

posts._title: Flora Gomes – Po di Sangui aka l’arbre aux armes AKA Tree of blood (1996)
posts.title: Po di Sangui
posts.excerpt: In the colorful forest village of Amanha Lundju, tradition demands that when a child is born a tree be planted. As the tree grows, it becomes the twin of the growing human being. At the same time, trees are constantly being felled for firewood and buildings, and the threat of organized deforestation by the state …
posts.titleEnglish: l’arbre aux armes AKA Tree of blood

posts.title: Demon
posts.excerpt: A bridegroom is possessed by an unquiet spirit in the midst of his own wedding celebration, in this clever take on the Jewish legend of the dybbuk.

posts._title: Elio Petri – La classe operaia va in paradiso AKA The Working Class Goes to Heaven (1971)
posts.title: La classe operaia va in paradiso
posts.excerpt: Quote: “Lulu the Tool” is no more descriptive a title for Elio Petri’s Italian social drama that opened yesterday at the D. W. Griffith Cinema than “La Classe Operaia Va in Paradiso” (“The Working Class Goes to Heaven”), the title under which it shared (with “The Mattei Affair”) the grand prize of the 1972 Cannes …
posts.titleEnglish: The Working Class Goes to Heaven

posts.title: My Hindu Friend
posts.excerpt: Quote: His father has died, he doesn’t speak for his brother for about 10 years and he has a serious cancer. Diego is a talented film director with difficulty to deal with his sickness, which is making him lose his friends and family slowly. His best friend and doctor, Ricardo, gives him the news that …
